message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the effects of smoking on the body. Smoking can directly affect the intensity of coughing. When a person smokes, the smoke irritates the lining of the respiratory system, causing inflammation and an increase in mucus production. This can lead to a persistent cough that is more intense than a non-smoker's cough. Option (A) is incorrect because smoking is not directly linked to hearing loss. Option (B) is also incorrect because while smoking can indirectly affect sleep by causing respiratory issues, it does not directly affect sleep. Option (D) is incorrect because smoking can actually suppress appetite and decrease hunger.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the effects of smoking on the body. Smoking can directly affect the intensity of coughing. This is because smoking irritates the lungs and airways, leading to increased mucus production and inflammation. As a result, individuals who smoke often experience a more intense and persistent cough compared to non-smokers. Option (A) is incorrect because smoking is not a direct cause of hearing loss. Option (B) is partially true, as smoking can disrupt sleep due to nicotine's stimulating effects, but it is not a direct effect of smoking. Option (D) is also incorrect because smoking can suppress appetite and lead to decreased hunger.

This question tests knowledge about the direct effects of smoking on the body. Smoking can directly affect the intensity of a person's cough. The chemicals in cigarette smoke irritate the lining of the respiratory system, leading to increased coughing. Option (A) is incorrect because while smoking can indirectly contribute to hearing loss through decreased blood flow to the ears, it is not a direct effect. Option (B) is incorrect because while smoking can affect sleep quality indirectly by causing respiratory issues or nicotine addiction, it is not a direct effect. Option (D) is incorrect because while smoking can suppress appetite and reduce hunger indirectly, it is not a direct effect.
